"Fly me to the Moon"
--Professor Wayman Scott
By MARK SHUSTED
Professor Wayman Scott, an accomplished member of
both the Hopkins' faculty and the Baltimore City School
Board, is one of the-most well-known and popular men on
campus.
.The first black appointed to Hopkins' faculty,
Professor Scott holds a doctorate in fluid dynamics and is
a part-time professor in the department of Earth and
Planetary Sciences. Furthermore, the professor, who is
51, has recently started his second term on the 13altimor
City Board of Education.
Born ,and raised in Oberlin, Ohio, Dr. Scott went to
Oberlin College and received his Ph.D. at Hopkins: "Like
most blacks, I viewed education as a means to an end, the
end being getting a job -- so I figured if I could major in
the most difficult course in the curriculum I could get a
job. The most difficult course was physics, so I majored in
physics in college and got a Master's degree in it, and for
me the most difficult part of physics was fluid dynamics,
so I got a Ph. D. in that."
Before arriving at Johns Hopkins, Professor Scott
taught at several state colleges and, as a result, his opinion
of the students here is high: "I've spent a lot of time
teaching in state institutions, schools where if you
graduated from high school you could get admitted. I've
had students in the college classes who couldn't read or
write; so I am tremendously impressed with the Hopkins'
students, maybe too impressed, because of my having
taught so much in the other schools. The students here
are outstanding."
Many of the non science-oriented students here are
familiar with Dr. Scott through his teaching of the
introductory ..course, Astronomy and the Solar System.
(Commonly called Astrogut.) According to the Professor,
his interest in astronomy was not accidental, but instead
resulted from his previous work in fluid dynamics: "The
core of the earth and some of the other planets is fluid,
and it is those fluid dynamical processes that give rise, so
the theory says, to the magnetic fields of the earth and
the planets. So I had a chance to apply my knowledge of
fluid dynamics to an astronomical problem, and thus I
became interested in astronomy."

However, because Dr. Scott employs a flamboyant
lecture style and is prone to the unearthing of
little-known iaformation, wary students often question
the factual basis of the lectures. To these complaints the
Professor replies: "I have read, I think, every astronomy
text in existence, and with that kind of background it is
wry easy to prepare the kind of lectures that I do."

Professor Scott finds satisfaction in helping to formulate
the policies of the Baltimoe City School Board, a body to
which he was recently renominated. by Mayor Schaefer.
The Board, however, far from ensuring that the public
schools are as good as they can be, has had difficulties
maintaining high standards of excellence in education in

recent years.
"No, the schools are not as good as they should be, but
this Board is going to make them better," declared Dr.
Scott. "I think that I helped change the Board's thinking
.-- that we should return to the basics in education. Let's
emphasize the fact that the youngsters must learn to read
and write -- that wasn't the emphasis four or five years
ago."
Dr. Scott's concern for education is by no means
limited to the Board, for he has been active in attempts to
expand and diversify the educational opportunities at
Hopkins. Despite these efforts, he still feels that many of
the students do not ta c advantage of the widening
curriculum.
"I am somewhat concerned with the tendency of the
students to specialize, hut that may be necessary. I do
think the students could be a little more well-rounded
than they are, but that's going to require more time, and
the time is not available.
"I did agree sonic years ago with the student
contention that the undergraduate program As not-as
broad as it should have been, but there's been a lot of
improvement in that area and maybe we can see some
more. That is, there weren't enough courses being offered,
on the undergraduate level. There are more now, but I am
not-quite sure if there are enough."
Of course, Professor Scott realizes that mere expansion
of the undergraduate curriculum will not guarantee
well-rounded students, and that .the ultimate aim of the
bulk of the students to reach graduate schools limits the
variety of courses one can take. "I think the solution is
going to lie with the medical schools and the graduate
schools, and as long as spaces are limited, you're going to
have to have this kind of competition."
Although these conditions may be harmful in some
respects, Professor Scott feels that, overall, receiving one's
education at Hopkins is a worthwhile experience. "I think
we are producing well-educated graduates. I believe the
graduate here knows something when he le;ivcs. The goal
of Hopkins is what it has always been, and that is to make
a contribution to society -- Hopkins has done that and iF
continuing to do that."

(CPS)-- What's an ex-President of the United States to
do? It can get boring while still in a transitional stage,
even if your pension is near the hundred grand mark and a
ton of golfing invitations flood your Secret
Service-protected office every day.
For Gerry Ford, the answer to escape that boredom is
to hit the always lucrative lecture circuit. Ford has kicked
off his series of "informal" visits to college campuses
around the country w ith a stop at his alma mater, Yale
University. He had started his law studies there 42
years-ago after a fair-to-middling scholastic record and a
distinguished football career at the University of
Michigan. At Yale he coached the football team and
eventually talked his way into the law school.
Ford spoke to several classes, touching upon a wide
range of topics with a guarded opinion. He said that one,
of his more regrettable decisions as president was not to
invite the Russian dissident-exile, Aleksandr I.
Solzhenitsyn, to the White House in 1975.
To further ease his retirement days, Ford has also been
appointed as an adjunct professor of political science at
the U. of Michigan for the next winter term. He'll be on
that campus for one or twol tek periods this calendar
year while his teaching schedule is being worked out on a
more permanent basis. Maybe he'll achieve the tenure he
missed in November.

In an interview appearing in the March 22 News-Letter,
I spoke of my intention, if elected, of producing a
Declaration of Principle for my term as Student Council
President. Though more of a letter than an actual
declaration (as part of an effort to strike all undue
formality from student government), I hope this
statement, will,serve to reaffirm my views and, amidst the
class primaries, perhaps define the guidelines by which the
incoming Council might operate.
The most general, all-encompassing duties of the
Student Council are to represent and act in the the
interests of the Hopkins undergraduates in all matters
directly or indirectly pertaining to them. However, in
order to to render credence to this proposition certain
fundamental conditions must be met.
First, it is absolutely necessary that the Council present
itself as a cohesive front for meeting student needs.
Therefore, upon assuming office for the coming academic
year, the entire Student Council membership must make a
conscious and concerted attempt to transcend all
bitterness and personal enmities (often arising from the
previous elections) that could possibly hamper Council
progress in any given direction. Unless completely devoid
of in-fighting, the Council will have damned itself from
the • start, leaving the possibilities of accomplishing
anything of long-term consequence negligible.
Second, the Student Council must seek the active
participation of the greatest possible number of
undergraduates in student
government. Not only will this promote more widespread
knowledge and understanding of important issues -- as
well as bring new issues to the fore -- but itwill greatly
facilitate Council action in areas w here strong student
reaction can produce an impact. It is also of paramount
importance that undergraduates know,who their Council
representatives are, and utilize them to the fullest as a
means of articulating their concerns. By way of regular
open forums (tentatively scheduled for . the second '

Tuesday of each month, in the Glass Pavilion) as -a
badly-needed supplement to the weekly Council meetings,
it is hoped that more students will avail themselves of the
opportunity to make themselves heard.
Third, the new Council must strive to develop a closer
rapport ,with the Hopkins faculty. Through revitalized
studentliasons to the individual departments, in addition
to the careful scrutiny of all facets of Hopkins education,
the Council and faculty together may take steos toward
the overall betterment of undergraduate academics.
Fourth, a more productive wor Icing relationship
between the Council and University administration must
be fortered. This does not entail passive submission to
administration must be fostered. This does not entail
passive submission to policies that blatantly conflicbwith
undergraduate interests, in which case it would be the
Council's duty to spearhead swift :)nd definitive measures
to counter such an action. Rather, it must be the purpose
of the Council, through a display of pragmatism and
sound judgment, to secure a welcomed role in all
policy-making that affects the undergraduate.
Once the above prerequisites have been fulfilled, the
Council will find itself in a position to implement those
changes it deems necessary to improve undergraduate
existence at Johns Hopkins -- everything from intersession
course-offerings to the day-to-day social life on campus.
The desire, the innovativeness, and the energy are readily
apparent -- only a clear and level-headed approach is
needed to see the plans through. It is simply a matter of
keeping our objectives practical -- .they need not be
modest.

Playwriting at Hopkins
By JOHN PERROTTA

Bob Arellano

Friday and Saturday at eight pm in the Little Theatre
undergraduates will once again demonstrate that
creativity does exist at Hopkins. Robert Arellano will
present six one-act plays written, directed, produced and
acted by the students in his play writing workshop. The
program mingles comedy and satire with realistic drama.
Student demand led to the birth of the play writing
courses in 1971. Arellano, an instructor in the Chemistry
Department, taught "Problem Drama" to a handful of
eager undergraduates. The "problems" they wrote about
were generally restricted to those at Homewood:
automatic vending machines in Levering Hall and the
inefficient University president who just wouldn't quit.
Interestingly enough, just before five plays were
performed, all dealing with President Lincoln Gordon's
inadequacies, he resigned his position at Johns Hopkins.
After the end of the Vietnamese War, protest plays were
replaced by real-life drama.
The young playwrights did not always enjoy the
benefits of Levering Hall's Little Theatre. They first
performed plays in Maryland Hall, the Garrett Room,the
J and H Rooms, and even in Shaffer 3. Many times stage
hands w ould arrange props and lights while a nervous
professor was trying to wrap up his lecture. Finally, Dean

Owen procured funds to buy floodlights and lumber for a
stage, and playwriting moved to its present'location. The
Little Theatre seats seventy comfortably, but Arellano
claims the record for cramming people ,in is one hundred
and two,counting those seated on the. window sills.
Robert Arellano left his native Cuba in 1959 and
received his B.A. and M .A. at the Massachusetts Institute
of Technology. He came to Johns Hopkins in 1961 as a
chemistry instructor; and enrolled in Writing Seminars
courses during his spare time. He received his M.A. from
that department the following year. .
Arellano's classes, including a quickie intersession
course, have performed over two hundred and fifty plays
since 1971. Actors are allowed not more than one week
to learn their lines. Intersession students are permitted a
mere three days.
Presently Arellano is busy supervising rehearsals of two
original plays: "Nicely Goodworth",
a chemical
comedy to be presented during the Spring Fair in Remsen
Hall, and "Eleven O'clock", to be presented the following
weekend. He is also preparing for a summer musical.
Says Arellano about drama and chemistry, "It's a very
good combination because you don't get bored." Indeed,
he is not the only one, as his course is ranked among the
top by students, and at show-time the Little Theatre is
almost always filled to capacity.

The recent article concerning attempts to force the
unionization of Southern textile plants was submitted by
the Yotnig Democrats. Yet, in a larger sense, the
characterizations of the evil magnate and the blameless
labor organizer are the creation of well-salaried curators
of public opinion. Fifteen million dollars of workers'
salaries buys many stereotypes.
The migration of the American textile industry to the
South is not solely the result of an attempt to avoid the
power of Union bosses. Management knows well that the
hirelings of Big Labor will travel, for a price. Non-union,
as well as organized, plants moved from the Northeast.
Other aspects of overhead costs-- power, taxes, and rent -influenced the decision.
The allegedly low wage scale of Stevens employees is
offered as evidence of management wrongdoing. To note.
only that the STevens worker receives somewhat less than
the averageAmerican factory worker does not take into
account differences in skill, cost of living, and job market
conditions. Any increase in wages gained by the union
will lead to higher prices, a higher cost of living, and
further wage demands. Neither should it be forgotten that
union membership ' costs both the worker and his
employer money; money that might otherwise go to
wagess and capital investment. And what service does the
union provide, that workers could not provide for
themselves without paying the union hierarchy?
If, as is alleged, laws have been violated, redress is
available. It were not as if employees needed to submit to
unionization in order to have their legal rights protected.
There is, however, an issue at stake that reaches well
beyond the Stevens plants, sweaty or not, beyond the
South, beyond even the media hirelings. Those who
support the forced unionization of'Stevens workers claim
for themselves the words "freedom" and "justice."
Regardless of the price paid out of the pockets of
American workers, these concepts cannot be bought.
They cannot be annexed to a cause that has, at its basis, a
system of political and economic coercion.
A union election is not what it seems. In the absence of
Right-to-Work Laws, derided by unionists, a bare majority
of workers in a single plant may force their fellow
employees to submit their own paychecks to union
siphoning, under pain of disemployment. There is no
freedom; there is compulsory deprivation of property.
Those unwilling workers who, valuing their livelihoods
over their indpendence, acquiesce to this dues-slavery lose
their political freedom as well. The supposed power of the
Meaneys and Woodcocks of the textile industry may in
the future be built on the backs of unwilling union
members. Their political support is subsumed wliAn the

labor bosses flaunt membership figures before officials.
There is no freedom; there is restraint of freedom of
'assocation. The same rationale that prompted the textile plants to

be relocated in the Sotith could, as easily, close them. The
same groups -- the same party -- that support the Stevens
venture oppose protectionism. The' two positions are
contradictory.

--Professor Wayman Scott
By MARK SHUSTED
Professor Wayman Scott, an accomplished member of
both the Hopkins' faculty and the Baltimore City School
Board, is one of the-most well-known and popular men on
campus.
.The first black appointed to Hopkins' faculty,
Professor Scott holds a doctorate in fluid dynamics and is
a part-time professor in the department of Earth and
Planetary Sciences. Furthermore, the professor, who is
51, has recently started his second term on the 13altimor
City Board of Education.
Born ,and raised in Oberlin, Ohio, Dr. Scott went to
Oberlin College and received his Ph.D. at Hopkins: "Like
most blacks, I viewed education as a means to an end, the
end being getting a job -- so I figured if I could major in
the most difficult course in the curriculum I could get a
job. The most difficult course was physics, so I majored in
physics in college and got a Master's degree in it, and for
me the most difficult part of physics was fluid dynamics,
so I got a Ph. D. in that."
Before arriving at Johns Hopkins, Professor Scott
taught at several state colleges and, as a result, his opinion
of the students here is high: "I've spent a lot of time
teaching in state institutions, schools where if you
graduated from high school you could get admitted. I've
had students in the college classes who couldn't read or
write; so I am tremendously impressed with the Hopkins'
students, maybe too impressed, because of my having
taught so much in the other schools. The students here
are outstanding."
Many of the non science-oriented students here are
familiar with Dr. Scott through his teaching of the
introductory ..course, Astronomy and the Solar System.
(Commonly called Astrogut.) According to the Professor,
his interest in astronomy was not accidental, but instead
resulted from his previous work in fluid dynamics: "The
core of the earth and some of the other planets is fluid,
and it is those fluid dynamical processes that give rise, so
the theory says, to the magnetic fields of the earth and
the planets. So I had a chance to apply my knowledge of
fluid dynamics to an astronomical problem, and thus I
became interested in astronomy."

However, because Dr. Scott employs a flamboyant
lecture style and is prone to the unearthing of
little-known iaformation, wary students often question
the factual basis of the lectures. To these complaints the
Professor replies: "I have read, I think, every astronomy
text in existence, and with that kind of background it is
wry easy to prepare the kind of lectures that I do."

Professor Scott finds satisfaction in helping to formulate
the policies of the Baltimoe City School Board, a body to
which he was recently renominated. by Mayor Schaefer.
The Board, however, far from ensuring that the public
schools are as good as they can be, has had difficulties
maintaining high standards of excellence in education in

recent years.
"No, the schools are not as good as they should be, but
this Board is going to make them better," declared Dr.
Scott. "I think that I helped change the Board's thinking
.-- that we should return to the basics in education. Let's
emphasize the fact that the youngsters must learn to read
and write -- that wasn't the emphasis four or five years
ago."
Dr. Scott's concern for education is by no means
limited to the Board, for he has been active in attempts to
expand and diversify the educational opportunities at
Hopkins. Despite these efforts, he still feels that many of
the students do not ta c advantage of the widening
curriculum.
"I am somewhat concerned with the tendency of the
students to specialize, hut that may be necessary. I do
think the students could be a little more well-rounded
than they are, but that's going to require more time, and
the time is not available.
"I did agree sonic years ago with the student
contention that the undergraduate program As not-as
broad as it should have been, but there's been a lot of
improvement in that area and maybe we can see some
more. That is, there weren't enough courses being offered,
on the undergraduate level. There are more now, but I am
not-quite sure if there are enough."
Of course, Professor Scott realizes that mere expansion
of the undergraduate curriculum will not guarantee
well-rounded students, and that .the ultimate aim of the
bulk of the students to reach graduate schools limits the
variety of courses one can take. "I think the solution is
going to lie with the medical schools and the graduate
schools, and as long as spaces are limited, you're going to
have to have this kind of competition."
Although these conditions may be harmful in some
respects, Professor Scott feels that, overall, receiving one's
education at Hopkins is a worthwhile experience. "I think
we are producing well-educated graduates. I believe the
graduate here knows something when he le;ivcs. The goal
of Hopkins is what it has always been, and that is to make
a contribution to society -- Hopkins has done that and iF
continuing to do that."

administration must be fostered. This does not entail
